Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I heard the front door slam and saw my little brother drop his backpack, his eyes red and puffy. He didn’t say anything, just shuffled past me toward his room. I knew something was wrong—he always tried to hide it, but I could tell. As his older sibling, I felt the pull to go after him, to sit on his bed and listen, to be the person he could lean on when the world felt too heavy. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: the petition deadline was in five minutes. I’d spent weeks rallying people for this cause, urging them to sign, and now I had one last chance to add my own name before it was sent to the senator. My heart pounded as I stared at the screen, torn between the urgent call to action and the quiet pain in the next room. I could hear my brother’s muffled sobs, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding I choose which mattered more in this moment.
